purpose: Sprint 2 teams — complementary problem domains from Sprint 1, score-balanced
note: Park Justin (CST395-17) missing from grades data — paired with strong anchor

teams.rationale: Fedeli's empathy and concrete habit-stacking approach can help Niazi move from abstract observations to specific design solutions; Niazi's coding/AI context gives Fedeli a new domain to apply design thinking

members.name: Fedeli, Joseph
members.problem: Snacking/health habits — habit-stacking, environmental placement

members.name: Niazi, Abdul Rauf
members.problem: Theory vs practice in development — needs specificity in analysis

teams.rationale: Morales's sophisticated friction/systems framework can help Olaoye structure their 'focused energy' insight into a concrete design opportunity; Olaoye's enthusiasm gives Morales a real coaching challenge

members.name: Morales, Augustin
members.problem: Friction and habit formation — environment shapes behavior

members.name: Olaoye, Oluwatobiloba
members.problem: Focused energy concept — enthusiastic but missing submissions

teams.rationale: Trujillo's strong facilitation and concrete task-breakdown approach make him an ideal anchor regardless of Park's situation; his iterative experimentation mindset models the course philosophy

members.name: Trujillo, Nathan
members.problem: Task breakdown + timing — non-tech and tech solutions

members.name: Park, Justin
members.problem: No Sprint 1 data available

teams.complementarity: Productivity tracking/environment design meets phone distraction
teams.rationale: Medina identified phone/computer location as a key design lever — directly relevant to Fletes's distraction challenge; Medina's accountability-focused questions can push Fletes to submit writing

members.name: Medina, Angel
members.problem: Hourly activity tracking with visual feedback, device location

members.name: Fletes, Carlos
members.problem: Phone/distraction — understood environmental design but didn't submit writing

teams.complementarity: Structured daily goals meets time-boxed sessions
teams.rationale: Both working on consistency but from different angles: Roberto's rigid-but-flexible structure vs Angel's 30-minute sessions with notifications — can cross-pollinate strategies and measure approaches against each other

members.name: Palacios, Roberto
members.problem: Music composition consistency — daily bite-sized goals, 'rigid structure with flexibility'

members.name: Valdez, Angel
members.problem: 30-minute sessions + notifications — needs to articulate design vs willpower distinction

teams.complementarity: Research workflow redesign meets planner consistency
teams.rationale: Both building personal productivity systems but at different layers: Daniel's Obsidian workflow mapping for research vs Edwin's planner process for daily activities — can share tools and approaches across scales

members.name: Orta, Daniel
members.problem: Research-driven workflow redesign in Obsidian — mapping to execution gap

members.name: Kofler, Edwin
members.problem: Planning consistency — adding activities to planner process

teams.rationale: Both struggling with the gap between planning and execution from different angles: Daniel's bottleneck converting research to output, Van's misestimation of task scope — complementary views on the same meta-problem

members.name: Martinez, Daniel
members.problem: Research-to-output bottleneck — 90-minute timer, coaching ability

members.name: Stewart, Van
members.problem: Task estimation/scheduling — recognized scope misestimation, not willpower

teams.rationale: Metke's conceptual understanding of systemic change can help Meza articulate *why* his scheduling solution works; Meza's concrete environment changes give Metke practical examples to ground his abstractions

members.name: Metke, Austin
members.problem: Systemic vs individual thinking — excellent facilitation, conceptual strength

members.name: Meza, Christian
members.problem: Consistency/scheduling + environment changes — collaborative growth mindset

teams.complementarity: Collaborative health design meets sleep environment design
teams.rationale: Both used physical/environmental design for health habits; Victoria's strong discussion skills complement Matthijs's strong writing but weak discussion — they balance each other's gaps

members.name: Cimino, Victoria
members.problem: Hydration habits — learned from partner's Prep Phase, strong collaborative learner

members.name: De Vries, Matthijs
members.problem: Sleep/wake-up routine — device relocation as environmental design

teams.complementarity: Learning style redesign meets reading friction reduction
teams.rationale: Both applied environmental/behavioral design in learning contexts: David's Prep Phase strategy across multiple projects vs Eduardo's friction reduction for reading — David's cross-project systems thinking pushes Eduardo to generalize, Eduardo's concrete metrics (10→30 min) ground David's approach

members.name: Orta, David
members.problem: Learning style mismatch — Prep Phase strategy, systems thinking across projects

members.name: Sanchez-Pereyra, Eduardo M.
members.problem: Reading habit — environmental friction design, tangible progress (10→25-30 min)
